H0.text: 4 light-years is the most accurate measurement of the distance between the Sun and its nearest neighboring star.

H1.text: 400 light-years is the most accurate measurement for describing the distance between the Sun and its nearest neighboring star.

H2.text: 4 billion kilometers is the most accurate measurement of the distance between the Sun and its nearest neighboring star.

H3.text: 400 billion kilometers is the most accurate way to describe the distance between the Sun and its nearest neighboring star.

A4.text: The distance of Alpha Centauri from the Earth is now reckoned at 4.396 light-years or 4.159×1013 km.

A5.text: Proxima Centauri is the closest star to the Sun at a distance of 4.24 ly (1.30 pc).

A6.text: Based on a parallax of 768.0665±0.0499 mas, published in 2020 in Gaia Data Release 3, Proxima Centauri is 4.2465 light-years (1.3020 pc) from the Sun.

A7.text: Proxima Centauri, the nearest star to Earth after the Sun, is located 4.25 light-years (1.3 parsecs) away in the southern constellation of Centaurus.

A8.text: A light-year, alternatively spelled light year (ly or lyr), is a unit of length used to express astronomical distances and is equal to exactly 9460730472580.8 km, which is approximately 9.46 trillion km or 5.88 trillion mi.

A9.text: The closest star to the Solar System, Proxima Centauri, is 269,000 AU (4.25 ly) away.
